title: Can you end a sentence with three dots? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, three dots, or rather an ellipsis (which is actually a single character), is often used to indicate that a sentence is not finished by the speaker, for example: “I’m not going to…” he said, but suddenly he realized that he had no choice and had to do it regardless. Note that an m-dash (—) can also indicate an unfinished sentence, but I prefer to use the m-dash to show that the speaker did not finish the sentence because he was interrupted by someone else.
No, three dots take the place of an omission. If you really need an omission at the end of a sentence, use four dots, the final one being the sentence’s ending punctuation, its period.
Dotty puzzled over ellipsis, thinking them tiny eclipses, a sentence might end but for two friends light-hearted and joined at the hipses…
